### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:The person gave a good hands on what to show how to do the work? Choices:  A: demonstration B: garage C: building D: barn E: synagogue<n>Output:		C: building<n>Input and output:<n><n>### Instruction:Write code to complete each function<n><n>* function to determine the person's answer is right or wrong<n><n>***<n><n>### Input and output<n><n>### Instructions:Write code to complete the following function so that the program will say true if the input is a palindrome and false if the input is not<n><n>function to check string to see if is a palindrome<n><n>Input: "kayak" Output: true<n>Input: "mom" Output: true<n><n>Input: "dog" Output: false<n>Input: "1222" Output: false<n><n>### Function A to return 0 if the input string not a palindrome else return 1<n><n>import std.string;<n>import std.array;<n>var i int;<n><n>function A(input:string)int<n>  var s:string;<n>  var i:int;<n>  s=input;<n>  i=0;<n>  for (;i< s.len()/2;i=i+1) {<n>    if (s[i]!= s[s.len()-i]) {<n>      return 0;<n>    }<n>  }<n>  return 1<n>end;<n><n>Testing:<n><n>Input: "abcba" Output: 1<n>Input: "cba" Output: 0<n><n><n>### Function B to return 0 if there is a character before the leftmost odd digit in the string else return 1<n>import std.string,<n>std.array;<n>var<n>  oddDigit:char<n>  i:int;<n><n>function B(input:string) : int<n>  oddDigit = char(input[input.len()-1]);<n>  i = input.len() - 1;<n>  println ( input.len() - oddDigit.val);<n>  if ( input!= input[i] )<n>    return 0;<n>  else<n>    return 1;<n>end;<n><n>Tests:<n><n>Input:  "123" Output: 1 (there is no character before the leftmost digit)<n>Input: "213" Output: 0 (leftmost digit is an odd digit)<n>Input:  "343" Output:  zero (leftmost digit

Chicago <n><n><n># Solution:<n><n><n>import re<n>noun = input("Noun: ")<n>question = input("Question: ")<n>answer = question.lower()<n>output = []<n>for char in question:<n>    if re.search("[aeiou]", char):<n>        output.append('/^[aeiou]$/')<n>    else:<n>        output.append(char)<n>if answer == "".join(output):<n>    print("true")<n>else:<n>    print("false")<n>'''<n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Though it stayed strictly indoors, the small dog felt like it had all the space in the world in the what? Choices:  A: living room B: dog park C: basket D: small apartment E: big house<n>Output:		A: living room<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. First of all, you have to import the whole module of python:<n>```  <n>import numpy as np<n>from sklearn.svm import SVC,SVR,LinearSVC <n>```<n>2. Next, you have to download the dataset <n>```  <n>dataset = pd.read_csv('/data/ml/gis/ml-gis-data/0067-female.csv')<n>train_dataset, test_dataset = dataset.iloc[:8000/2,:20], dataset.iloc[8000/4:,:20]<n>y_train, y_test = y_train['Label'], y_test['Label']<n>```<n>3. Next train the model on the training dataset in 2 passes: <n>```  <n>##first pass<n>clf = SVC(C=0.01)<n>#train_dataset.iloc[3000:,:20].to_csv('svc_0067.csv',index= False)<n>clf.fit(train_dataset.illoc[3000:],y_train[:3000,])<n><n>##second pass<n>clf = SVR(C=0.1)<n>#train2_dataset.iloc[:3000],y_train[3000 :].to_csv('regress_00673.csv',index=False)<n>clf.predict(train2_dataset[:])<n>```<n>4. Finally, predict on the test dataset:<n>```  <n>clf=LinearSVC(C=0.2)<n>y_pred = clf.predict(test_dataset.iloc  )<n>y_pred<n>```<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:What is committing perjury likely to lead to? Choices:  A: shame B: arrest C: embarrassment D: go to jail E: tension<n>Output:		A:shame<n><n>### Explaination<n><n>In programming a typical multiple choice question is a series of if-else statements and the multiple choice inputs  have be matched with the statements<n><n>For example:<n><n>```<n>a = ['movie theatre', 'university', 'park', 'alaska', 'country'];<n>b = ['arrest', 'go to jail'];<n>c = ['committing perjury', 'tension'];<n>```<n><n>To solve this problem you will need to know the number of input choice for this question and the number of choices for the output choices.<n><n>First, use the length function len(...) to determine the total number of choice for the answer.<n><n>Second, you also need to figure out the number of choices of each choices you are going to use in the problem.<n><n>After you get all these you can create an array that has all the choice for each choice from the questions and the answers.<n>Now you can check all the choice to find the matched choice and output on a specified variable.<n>To make sure you are on the right track if your code is not outputting the correct answer to the test case then the length of choices in a is the same as the length of choices of in b<n>If the value of a doesn't match the value of b then the algorithm is wrong.

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:If you did well on the test, you might get an A as a what? Choices:  A: see work B: practice C: quiz D: school grade E: homework<n>Output:		B: practice<n><n>Input:What happened when we took our friend to the park? Choices: A: We saw a squirrel. B: We got a lot of sun. C: We saw a car. D: We took a nap. E: We saw lots of cars.<n>Output:E: We saw lots of car<n><n>Input:What does the farmer do with his land? Choices: A : uses it B: own it C: rents it E: buys it<n>Output:B: own it<n>Input: Where was the last house where you looked for a friend? Choices: A. Your mother’s home. B. Your father’s home. C. Your grand mother’s home. D. Your grand father’s home. E. Your other grand mother’s home<n>Output:C: Your grand mother’s Home<n>Input: What did you do at school today? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Where is a fox likely to be caught? Choices:  A: tennessee B: inside joke C: grassy field D: the forrest E: england<n>Output:		E: england<n><n>Your task is to write the program that answers both input question. Use any programming language you like but keep these two rules: the code should be self-contained, and it should compile on [codepad](http://codepad.org/).<n><n>### Note:<n><n>- Don't code just for the multiple choice questions, rather, answer the "What about this" questions also.<n>- Bonus points for code that are clear and maintainable. Hint: Use some comments to add explanations.<n><n>---<n><n>You can try this code first. This will be automatically regenerated and will be the basis of your submission!<n><n>```python<n>from math import asin<n>import time<n>import math<n><n>def dist_tokens(*t):<n>    return sum((x **2 for x in t)) ** 0.5<n><n>def run_time(f, N):<n>    def helper(*a):<n>        t1 = time.time()<n>        f(*a)<n>        return t1<n><n>    return helper<n><n>def part1(t, N):<n>    return sum(t ** 2 for i in range(N))<n><n>def part2(j, x, y, q, N):<n>    kmin = min(j, j - x * (j - q)) / ((j - q) * (q - 3))<n>    if kmin >= N:<n>        return 0<n>    return j - x * (kmin + q - 3)                                                                           #<n><n>N = int(input("Number of tokens in the input list:"))<n>q = int(input("How many tokens can the query point take:"))<n>t = input().split()<n><n>p1 = part1(t,N)<n>p2 = part2(q, N, 3 + (q - 2) // 2, q)<n>print("Part 1:", p1)<n>print("Part2:", p2)<n>```<n><n>---<n><n>## Test cases<n><n>**Input**<n>```python<n>Movie Theatre<n>University<n>Park<n>Alaska<n>Country<n><n>How far away from a point of co-ordinates (0,0) must you be, in metres, to be in Alaska?<n><n>Input: Where is a fox likely be seen <n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:The camper looked up at the vast night sky, it left him feeling mighty what? Choices:  A: unimportant B: insignificant C: stellar D: somewhat E: helpless<n>Output:		E: helpless <n><n>Given a string containing a sentence, each question will be 4 choices, two correct and two incorrect. The correct answer will be highlighted and must start with your chosen answer.<n><n>If a question has more than one correct answer, your job is to choose both, otherwise all answers will be highlighted and you will get all points. Choose between the two correct answers.

I think this is what the assignment is asking the user to code.<n><n>I tried out the code on this page: https://codepen.io/happyhari/pen/KXGwQG<n><n>#Program for this section<n><n>import random<n><n>def choose_word(wordsArr, userInput):<n>    # Choose a word at random and return it<n>    currentWords = wordsArr<n>    while len(currentWords) < 2:<n>        # If the user inputted an invalid entry then loop<n>        for i in range(0, len(currentWords)):<n>            if(currentWords[i] == userInput):<n>                # If user input is in the current word, and no more choices<n>                currentWords = []<n>                return userInput<n><n>        # If no choices left in the choices array, just return the last word<n>        currentWords = [] + currentWords<n>        # Otherwise, if there are choices, just append the new word<n>        currentWods = [] + currentWods<n><n>        # Pulls a new word and appends it to the current words<n>        randomWords = currentWords[0] + currentWords[1]<n>        currentWords.append(randomWords)<n><n>        # Pushes the new word into the current list<n>        wordsArr.append(randomWods)<n><n>result = []<n>randomWords = []<n>randomWods = []<n><n>wordsArr = ["Baby", "House", "Cat", "Dog", "Asteroid", "Bottle", "Sister", "Bike", "Moon", "Earth", "Water", "Tree"]<n><n>userChoice = input("Enter your choice in the following manner: \"word A or word B\". ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:The sample needed to be pure, but the lab assistant got it what? Choices:  A: corrupt B: applied C: dirty D: contaminated E: fresh<n>Output:		D: contaminated<n><n>Input:The man is a mathematician because the number of hours per day are the same, Choices:  A : true B : false C: is false D: not a number<n>Output: D: not a number.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>If there's only one answer that's correct, then the question is either stupidly obvious, or stupidly wrong. This is a way to make it look like you're providing some value in the question. <n><n>Sometimes there's answers with partial right/wrong to the answer. Some answers might look wrong but might be close to what they're trying to ask. You might guess the correct answer, then get a close answer. <n><n>Same answer as before. If there's only one correct answer, is it obvious or wrong? And if only one is correct, the other is wrong.<n><n>The numbers might work. The question might have an answer like "this many pounds in a truck." Then give all the weights that would fit in the truck.<n><n>**Bonus 1:**<n><n>For bonus answer, this should show you all the correct answers to the questions. <n><n>You'll see the number of choices increase in size as you go through one, to two, three, and at the end, four.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Where might you have cake with your ice cream? Choices:  A: earth B: movie C: party D: served cold E: freezer<n>Output:		C: party<n><n>```python<n>import re<n><n># Solution Code<n>def solution(cityIdea):  # Definition for type cityIdea. The input to this function could be "movie theatre" or "alaska" <n>    # print ("Cities are cool")<n>    return re.search('(\w\W){3,}', cityIdea).group(0) <n><n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    print("\nExample")<n>    print("Expected:  'Centre of town park, the university, and the movies'")<n>    print(solution("Where do humans go in cities? Choices: "<n>'"A: movie theatre ","B: university ","C: park ","D: alaska ","E: country"'))<n>    print("Exceeded: 'Wherever she goes'")<n>    print("")<n>```<n><n>### Instruction:<n><n>```python<n>Input:<n>Where are humans?<n>Choices:<n>A: the air.<n>B: university.<n>C: on the streets.<n>D: the library.<n>E: farmland.<n><n>Output:A: the air. <n><n>Explanation: A is the correct answer.<n>```<n><n># Input.<n><n>### Instructions: Answers the following multiple-choice question<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Explanation <n><n>### Solution code<n><n>### Code<n><n>```python<n>if __name__=="__main__":<n>    print("\nExpectation:")<n>    print("A: on the streets.")<n>    print("B: university.")<n>    print("C: the library.")<n>    print("D: farmland.")<n>    print("E: air.")<n>    print("") <n>    print("Examples:\n")<n><n>    print("")  <n>    print("\nThe library")<n>    print("<n>")        <n>    print("\nUniversity")<n>    print("University<n>")<n><n>```<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Analyze the input as a multiple choice problem with these<n>choices. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:James's bouncing rubber balls were at rest, and so he could sleep.  He would get up in the morning, and then put them in what state again? Choices:  A: upside down B: in motion C: active D: wakefulness E: resthold<n>Output:		B: in motion<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>## Solution one<n><n>```javascript<n>var input = "Where do humans go in cities, to be in nature?"<n><n>if(input.toLowerCase().indexOf("go") > -1 && input.toLowerCase().length > 2) {<n><n>    if(input.toLower() === "in nature where do" || input.toLowerCase() === "do nature where") {<n>    <n>        return "B: in motion"<n><n>    }else{<n>        <n>        return "A: where do humans go?"<n>        <n>    }<n><n>}else{<n><n>    return false<n><n>}<n><n>```<n><n>## Solution two<n><n>```javascript<n>function question_one(question) {var correctAnswer = ["in motion"];<n><n>var userAnswer = prompt(question);<n>switch(true) {<n><n>    case(userAnswer === "B: in motion") {<n>        <n>        return true;<n><n>    }else if(userAnswer === "A: where do they go?") {<n>        <n>    }else{return false;<n>    }<n>}<n><n>}<n><n><n>function question_two(question) {<n><n>var correctAnswer = ['active','sleep'];<n>userAnswer = prompt(question)<n><n>switch(true)<n>{<n>    case(useranswer === "active")<n>    {<n>        return true;  <n>    }<n>    else if (userAnswer === "in rest")<n>    {<n>        <n>    return true;<n>       <n>    }<n><n>    else<n>    {<n>         return false;<n><n>    } <n><n><n>}<n><n>}    <n><n><n>```<n>

Only cards above and below can be played.<n><n>### Instruction:#Write the following problem on a piece of paper and explain its purpose to your partner:<n><n>- Define and explain the term “Pythagorean Theorem”<n>- If you had to create a game that required players to do the Pythagorean Theorem, how would you set up the game?<n>- What numbers would you use for the first card and second card?<n>- What is the outcome of the game, and is there anything you have to watch out for if the numbers are the same?<n><n>### Instutcions:Read the prompts below and explain how you would set up a trivia game where one side does better than the other:<n><n>- Choose a game type that has 3 or less players<n>- Set up two sides that play against each other<n>- Write the first 5 to 10 questions and the correct answer<n><n>Choose an appropriate scoring system for the game:<n>Score: 5-4-3-2-1<n>Grade: 88-87-86-85-84<n>Number of players: 2-4<n><n>### Instructions:Read the following instructions and fill in the blank. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Where are all participants likely to need sports equipment? Choices:  A: dicks sporting goods B: sporting event C: mall D: sears E: sporting goods store<n>Output:		D: sears<n><n>Input: What are the two most common causes of accidents in a household appliance? Choices: 	A: light socket and blender B: toaster and stove C: stove and washer D: stove and blender<n><n>Output: C: stove and blende<n><n>Input: In which sport do you most often fumble the ball? Choices: <n><n>A: american football B: soccer C: basketball D: rugby<n><n>Output: B: soccer<n><n>Input: Which two cities are most likely to be considered hazardous to your health?Choices: <n>A: new york, new york B: washington, dc C: seattle, washington D: los angeles, california E: new york, california <n>Output: B: washington and D.C.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>I am going to provide the entire solution at the end. However, do not simply look at the solution to answer this question. Try to figure out the solution yourself!!<n><n>### Thoughts:<n><n>I can think of so many ways to do this program.  One way that I can think of off the top of my head without coding involves making the question <n><n>a series of if statements like this.<n>```<n>if (x==A){<n>	if (y==B){<n>		y=3;<n>	}<n>}<n>```<n>where I am basically trying to make a if..then..else..<n>How do I do this in one line?<n>### Solution: <n>This was one of the simplest and most elegant solutions I could think of. The key is to use an if...else... in a conditional statement and not in a series. Try doing this and see if you can think of ways to do it as efficiently. <n>```<n>if(q=='a'){if(p=='b'){<n>	p='c';<n>}else if{<n>	p='d';<n>}<n>}<n>else{p='e';}<n><n>```

Choices:  A B) stabilizer   C) magnifier   D) editor E) camera<n>Output: B) stabilizer<n><n>Input:Do people ever eat at the table while sitting on the couch? Choices:  Yes A: Sure B: No C: Nope<n>Output: A: Sure<n><n>#import "AppDelegate.h"<n><n>#import <UIKit/UIKit.h><n><n>@interface AppDelegate : UIResponder <UIApplicationDelegate><n><n>@property (strong, nonatomic) UIWindow *window;<n><n>@end<n><n>@implementation AppDelegate<n><n>- (BOOL)application:(UIApplication *)application didFinishLaunchingWithOptions:(NSDictionary *)launchOptions<n>{<n>    self.window = [[UIWindow alloc]<n>                   initWithFrame:[[UIScreen mainScreen] bounds]];<n>    // Override point for customization after application launch.<n>    UISplitViewController  *split = [[UISplitViewController alloc] initWithNibName:nil bundle:nil];<n>    split.delegate = self;<n><n>    [split setTransitionStyle:UISplitViewControllerStyleDoubleMaster];<n><n>    HomeViewController *home = [[HomeViewController alloc] initWithNavigator:self navController:split];<n><n><n>    // add all view controllers to the controller stack<n>    [split setViewControllers:[NSArray arrayWithObjects:home, nil]];<n><n>    self.window.rootViewController = split;<n>    [self.window makeKeyAndVisible];<n><n>    return YES;<n>}<n><n>#import "Navigator.h"<n>#import "HomeViewController.h"<n>#pragma mark splitviewc<n>- (void)splitViewController:(UISplitViewController *)splitViewController willHideViewController:(UIViewController *)viewController completed:(void (^)(void))complete {<n>    [super splitViewController:splitViewController willHide:viewController];
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:The small cabin was not available, so they were upgraded to what? Choices:  A: villa B: spacecraft C: hall D: palace E: hotel<n>Output:		A: villa<n><n>Input:What are your top concerns about getting vaccines: A. It is an aborted fetus. B: It's too expensive. C: If I got vaccinated, I'm still at risk of spreading the disease to others. Choices (A)-(C): Answer (D): It's free.<n><n><n><n>### Explanations<n>> A: Villa means a small home in the country. C: Park is a place where humans go to be in nature.<n>> <n>> B: Spacecraft means that the small cabin was not available but you were upgraded to one. D: Palace means you were upgraded to travel in style by going to a hotel to stay overnight.<n>> <n><n><n>## Explanation<n>There are two ways you can answer the input and produce the output, <n>1 - find which choice out of the options contains two letters of the first two letters of the input word and get the value of its alphabetical ordinal. Example:<n>If you are given **A** as input, check whether that letter is contained in any of the choice, if it is, then assign value of that option letter to **ordinal** variable<n>and if it is not contained then move on to the next choice, let's say, you found that the input **A** is contained in **villa** option and the second letter of that choice is **a** which corresponds to the value **@**, thus the output will be **villa** since there is only one choice  and its ordinal value is **@**.<n><n>2 - Second method, is checking if there exist an input word which is a substring of any of the options, If there is, extract that word and assign its value to the **ordinal** value variable in an array. if the length of the input is greater than 2 then you have to do the above checking again for another pair after removing one letter that was already extracted<n>in order to make sure that no letter that exist in the input is contained in the second pair.<n><n>> If we check the input A, there is no such option, so it takes the value of the first letter of the string, **A**<n><n>> If we take the input B, because the second letter of the string,**b** is contained in the same word that matches the first letter, namely : **A**,

Choices:  (a) the next week (b) the first time (c) the first marriage (d) the first divorce (e) the first divorce<n>Output: (d) the first marriage<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>```js<n>const chooseAnswer = (questions) =>{<n>    for (let question of questions){<n>        let answers = question.split(" : ");<n>		<n>        function choose(answer){<n>            alert(answers[0]) === answer? alert("correct") : alert("incorrect")<n>            return answer;<n>            }	<n>        choose(answers[1])<n>    }<n>}<n><n>function printQuestion(answer){<n>        if (answer === "A" || answer === "B" || answer === "C" || answer === "D" || answer === "E"){<n>            alert("C: " + answer)<n>        }else<n>            alert("A: " + answer) || alert("B: " + answer)|| alert("C: " = answer)<n>            || alert("D: " + answer)  || alert("E: " + answer)}	<n><n><n>    const questions = [<n>        ["Are humans monogamous?", "Hell no, some are polygamus."],<n>        [<n>            "What business has a tower top transmit signals?",<n>            "B: toronto, city",<n>            "c: radio station",<n>            "e: medieval castle",<n>            "A: city",<n>        ],<n>        ["

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:James was cooking s stew in his apartment kitchen.  Where might he look for a potato. Choices:  A: restaurants B: casserole C: root cellar D: pockets E: pantry<n>Output:		C: root cellar<n><n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```python<n>def solution(input):<n>    '''<n>    :param input:<n>    :return:<n>    '''<n>    arrGuesses = input.split(',\n')<n>    for guess in arrGuesses:<n>        guess = guess.strip(' ')<n>        if guess.lower() == 'park':<n>            return "C"<n>        elif guess.lower() == "restaurants":<n>            return "A"<n>        elif guess == "root cellar":<n>            return "C'<n>    return 'N/A'<n>                                                           <n>```<n><n>### Discussion<n>This question required us to parse commas as the delimiter, and we needed to compare letters in the answer given with the one we get from the user <n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Where did his wife ask him to look first when he complained of missing deodorant? Choices:  A: grocery store B: nightstand C: armpits D: own bathroom E: medicine chest<n>Output:		D: own bathroom<n><n># Input: Where was he asked to find his wife’s watch? Choices: <n># A: grocery story B: night stand C: armpits<n># D: own bathroom <n># E. medicine chest<n>import time<n>class Solution(object):<n>    def myAtoi(self, s):<n>        # Write your code here. Read input from stdin.<n>        t=time.clock()<n>        st=time.strftime("%Y-%m-%d at %H:%M:%S", time.localtime())<n>        start=input()<n>        st=''+st+' '+start<n>        st=''+start[:-1]+st[-1:].upper() <n>        st=''+' '+st[:2]+st[-2:]+'.'+st<n>        i=0<n>        while i<len(st):<n>            if st[i]=='-': st=st[:i]+" " +'0'*(-1*len(st[:i]))+'0'+" "+st[i:]<n>            else:     st=st[:i] +" "+str(int(float(st[i])))+" "+st[i:]              <n>            i+=1<n>        if st.isdigit():<n>            l=[i for i in range(int(len(st))/2)]<n>            print(" ".join([st[i]+st[i:i+1] if i+1<=int(len(st)/2) else st[i+1:] for i in l]))<n><n><n>        end=time.strftume("%Y-%m-%dd at %H:%M%S", time.localtme())<n>        print("")<n>        print('Total time is'+ str(time.clock()-t)<n>        print(end, 'took',<n>        int((time.time() - end)*1000),'ms to run ')<n>        print("") <n>

Choices: Dust, hair<n>Output: Dust, hair <n>	<n>Input: What do you want people to do when you're singing karaoke? Choices: Sing well<n><n>Input:Why was the tiger in the cage so happy? Choices: He escaped from the zoo.<n>```<n><n>## Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>```JAVA<n>//Write code for the main function in the main.java file<n>System.out.println("Please use proper English when you answer the question below!")<n>System.out.print("What could someone be doing in a park while performing that cannot be experienced by deaf people? ");<n>CharMatcher matcher = CharMatcher.anyOf("ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ");<n>String userInput = Character.toString(System.in.read());<n>if (!matcher.matches(userInput)) {<n>	System.out.println(true);<n>} else {<n>	System.exit(1);<n>}<n>System.out.toString();<n>```<n><n>## How did you approach the word-recognition problem?<n><n>I used tokenize and charMatcher to check if the user input contains alphabets, and then convert the string into a boolean variable (boolean flag), if the first char is lower letter and first char after that is upper letter, the char is a valid letter.<n><n><n>###

In this example, <n>`['Beac','m', 'art','music']` would be the most fun places and `'art'` would be the most fun thing to do.<n><n>### Instructon:Please comment your solution<n><n>#### Solution<n>Input:<n>[<n>  {<n>    'name': 'Bristol',<n>    'climate': 'hot',<n>    'nature': [],<n>    'entertainment': [<n>      'theatre',<n>     'sport'<n>    ]<n>  },<n>  {<n>    name: 'Nash',<n>    climate: 'hot',  <n>    'nature':'water',<n>    'entertain':['']<n>  }<n>  ]<n><n>Result:<n>[<n>  {'climate': 'hot', 'nature': ['water'],<n>    'entertain':'theater', 'diversions':[]},<n>  {'climate' :'',<n>    'natures': ['water'],<n>  'diversions':'water'<n>    }<n>]<n><n>### Test Case 1<n>nature='water'<n><n>### TestCases 2<n><n>'theater','sport'<n><n>### Solution<n>### Step 1<n><n>define a function 'funtionName' which accepts two input arguments, a string and a list of cities, return new object based on input string and the list(city).<n><n>### Step 2<n><n>define two variable 'name' and 'climate', <n>define two list which will be the nature and entertainment.<n>define another variable '
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:They don't get grades or sit at desks, but crowds of fish do what? Choices:  A: pets B: fills the pond C: attempt to fly D: school together E: breath in water<n>Output:		E: breath in water<n><n><n>### Explanation: We can use a greedy algorithm for part 1 by comparing strings using the Damerau-Levenshtein distance metric.<n>- We can first get the levenshtein distance, which is the weighted sum of the following:<n>```<n>Distance(x,y) =<n>        +----------------+<n>        | (x_i, y_i) + (x_i, x_i) |<n>        |----------------+<n>        |                 |<n>        | (y_i, x_j) + (y_i, y_j) |<n>        | (x, x_j) - (y, y_j) + (x, x_i) + (y, y_i) |<n>                     +-----++---+<n>```<n>- For O's, we add one to the last character for each A. We do the same for B's in the other string, adding 2. For A's or B's, we add 3 to the total.<n>- To get the damerau-levenshtein distance, we just do a simple math operation which gives the distance we were looking for.<n>This way, for x, and y, we can say that they're equal if and only if the damerau-lvevenshtein distance between x and y is 0.<n><n><n>### <n><n>#### Author: Andrew Ping<n><!-- If you'd like to work on an exercise, let me know and I can enable your editor access. --><n><n>#### Instructions<n><n>1. [ ] [In the comments, answer the question from the problem statement](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pNm0_KK6dKQ)<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:What would a camper need to do before he or she can start cooking food? Choices:  A: make breakfast B: go hiking C: pack or bag D: light fire E: grab a match<n>Output:		B: go hikking<n><n>Input: At which season you should plant sunflowers? Choices:  Summer A: spring B: Winter C: autumn<n>Output: B: Winter<n><n>Input:  "how is nature?" Choices:  A lot of trees. B less than 15 minutes. C a lot of animals. D 33% of earth. E all of the above.<n>Output:  C: a lot of animals<n><n>#Code<n><n>"""<n>def multipleChoice(question, choices=None):<n>    """<n>    This a fun little function to practice with<n>    It takes a few inputs and has fun in the process.<n>    #<n>    # Inputs:<n>    question - the question to be answered<n>    choices - if not passed return all the choices<n>    #<n>    """<n><n>    # print(question)<n>    # print(choices)<n><n>    print(choice(question, choices)) # this will return a choice from choices if passed<n>        if question == "C: park":<n>            return(("You chose C: park")<n>    elif question == "B: go hiking":<n>        return(("You chose B: go hikting") )<n>    elif question == ("B: movie theatre"):<n>        return(("you chose B: movie theatre") )<n>    elif choice == "A: summer":<n>        return( ("You chose A: summer" ) )<n>    elif choice=="B: autumn":<n>        return( ( "You chose B: autumn") )<n>    elif(choice=="B: Winter") :<n>        return("You Choose: B: winter" )<n>    elif(c == "C: a lot of animals") :<n>        return(("Answered: C: a lot of animal") )<n>    elif (c == "all of the above"):<n>        return("You choose: all of the above")<n><n>#Test code<n>def main():<n>    questions = multipleChoice(input("What is nature?"), choices = [ "a lot of trees", "a lot of animals", "very little trees", "very few animals", "none"])<n><n>main()<n><n><n>"""<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:What group of musicians will include someone playing the cello? Choices:  A: ocean B: symphony C: band D: music store E: music shop<n>Output:		D: music store<n><n>Input: What season is considered spring, during which many animals are born? Choices: 1: winter 2: fall 3: spring 4: summer 5: autumn<n>Output: 5: autumn <n><n>### Solution:<n><n>First input, Park is one of the answer and alaska is only one.<n>Therefore, alaska is eliminated as we have one of the answer<n><n>Second input, Music store is an answer.<n>Therefore, University is eliminated.<n><n>Third input, autumn is one of our chosen answer,<n>Therefore, spring is eliminated<n><n><n>

Choices:  What:  A: 5 states B: 40 states C: 1,000,000 acres D: 100 miles E: 100,00 miles<n>Output: E: 10,000, 000 miles<n><n>Input:Where will a dinosaur go to get a ride? Choices:  Where: A: museum B: zoo C: ocean D: car E: bus<n>Output: B: zoo<n><n>Input:Where is it? Choices: Where: A:  The zoo zoo B: The zoo zoo zoo C: The zoo zoo zoo and more D: The zoo zoo zoo zoo E: The zoo zoo zoo in the world<n>Output: D: The zoo zoo zoos in the world<n><n>Input:Who lived on a tree on a trunk? Choices:Who: A: Fred B: George C: Mary D: Adam E: Bob<n>Output:D: Adam<n><n>Input:What’s the word? Choices:What: A: 5 states of the sea floor b: sea floor<n>Output:A: 5 states of sea floor<n><n>Input:What kind of tree is the first one? Choices: Tree: A: tree B: bush C: flower D: grass E: fern<n>Output:A: tree<n><n>Input:What is that? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:At the end of your meal what will a waiter do? Choices:  A: serve food B: eat C: set table D: serve meal E: present bill<n>Output:		B: eat<n><n>Input: How will a bear eat a trout? Choices:  ABCDE<n><n>### Instruction:<n><n>This can be solved by using a state machine.<n><n>A state machine simulates the behavior of a target entity. It maps the target entity's states to actions the device should perform.<n><n>In the code, we store the behavior of the device as a state machine. Based on the current state in the state machine, the device will perform an action. The behavior stored in the state machine corresponds to the human's answer.<n><n>### Questions<n><n>- What are the pros/cons of using a state machine for the problem?<n><n>  Pros: <n><n>    - State machine can be easily constructed and is very lightweight. <n><n>    - Can easily implement a lot of states.<n><n>    - Can reuse the state machine when encounter any similar problem in the future.<n><n>  Con: <n><n>    The state machine requires a lot of coding and is difficult to implement state machine if you have no prior knowledge.<n><n>- Explain the decision tree in the code. How does your code generalize to solve more questions?<n><n>  In the state machine, the state machine will jump to different nodes and perform different behaviors. As we construct the state machine, we'll encounter situations where the next state is not obvious. In that case, you can use decision trees to find which next state to move to. <n><n>- In the code, you've used 3 nodes (A,B,C). How does the code scale to more complex state machines?<n><n>  To create more complex state machines, you can use nested ifs or for-loops to create a more complex tree.<n><n>  See: https://youtu.be/4jLrF4p5Vw8?t=1699 (video linked to code) for more details.<n> <n><n>### Credits:<n><n>[Code and Video](https://github.com/Tengzhikr/Udacity-Robotics-with-Java/blob/master/2019/week7/src/main/java/com/robowrathler/behaviors/state/StateMachine.java)<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:I'm looking for alcohol and fried foods, any suggestions? Choices:  A: pub B: plane C: beer D: store E: fraternity house<n>Output:		C: beer<n><n><n><n>"""<n>#!/bin/python<n># -*- coding: utf-8 -*-<n><n>import sys<n><n><n>def main():<n>    global ans<n><n>    input_lines = []<n><n>    for line in sys.stdin:<n>        if not line.strip():<n>            continue<n>        else:<n>            input_lines.append(line)<n><n>    total_cns = len(input_lines) / 2<n>    print total_cns - 1<n><n>    for q_i in range(q_start, q_end):<n>        # get choice A<n>        print q_i<n>        choice_A = input("Choice A: ")<n>        choice_B = ''<n>        # get choice B<n>        print choice_A<n>        choice_choices = list(range(len(input_lines)))<n>        while (choice_B not in choice_choices) or \<n>                (Choice_B not in input_lines[1]):<n>            print 'Invalid choice, please type in again.'<n>            choice_B = input("Choice B: ")<n>        print choice_B<n>        ans[choice_i] = [choice_A, choice_choices[choice_B - 1]]<n><n><n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    main()<n><n>"""<n><n>"""<n>if __name__=='__main__':<n>#    ans is used to store the choice A and the next choice B, which is in a row.<n>    ans = []<n>    input_lines=["Where do humans go in cities?"]<n>    q_start = 0<n>    q_end = 1<n>    n = len(input_text)<n>    for q_choice in range(q_end):<n>        input_lines.append('Choice A: '+ans[q_choice][0])<n>    input_lines.append("Choice B: ")  # we are looking for where 'A' lead to<n>    input_lines[1]=input([ans[q_choice-0][1]])<n>    print input_lines<n>

Choices: A: small  B: medium  C: large  D: xeriscape E: ecosystem<n>Output:C: large<n><n>Input:  What is an advantage of a xeriscape garden? Choices: 	A: plants are able to grow without watering B: plants are able to survive in any climate  C: plants are able to be cared for by anyone  D: plants are able to attract butterflies  E: plants are able to provide food for the soil<n><n>Output: B: plants are able  to grow without watering<n><n>### Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question.(116.37 points)<n><n>Input: Which of the following is the BEST explanation of why the leaves of the plant become yellow?  Choices: A:	the plant is getting old B:	a pest is attacking the plant C:	the plant is not getting enough light D:	the plant is experiencing drought E: the plant is over fertilized<n>Output: A:	the pant is getting old<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>Input:  How do humans water plants on a farm? Choices:  A: kick the bucket B: mortal C: dead D: can die E: dying<n>Output:		D: can die<n>```<n><n>### Code<n><n>```python<n># This is an example of the format of the questions you will be given<n># in your test<n>if x=='a' or x=='b' or x=='c' or x=='e':<n>    print ('c')<n>if x=='d' or x=='a'or x=='b'or x=='e': <n>    print('d')<n>else:<n>    print('e')<n>```<n><n>## 2. Multiple Input<n>* The format of the input is as follows: each line should start with a sentence and  then come a list of questions, one per line. A sentence might look like "Which animal is most likely to attack a human?"  <n>* Each question should have "answer" following it, on the same line. The answers are 0's and 1's (so you have to be careful of capitalization to make sure you're not accidentally giving the wrong answer).<n><n>### Instructions: Answer all these questions and print a summary of their answers. Include all your work so far,<n><n>Input: Which animals have the most flexible spines? Spine length in meters. <n>[8] Answer 0 or 1 for spine_length. If 0, spine_length is more than 2 meters. If 1, it is less than 2 meters.<n>Output: 0   0   0   1   0   0   0   Summary answer: 0<n>Input: What animal uses it's nose to smell? answer 0 or 1   1   1   1  0<n>Output: 1   Summary answer:  1 and answer1 Summary: 4<n>Input: What animal do you find hiding inside the shells of scallops? answer 0 or1   0   1   1    1<n>Output: 1   1    <n>Summary answer: 1<n>```<n><n>##3. Multiple Output<n>* The format is the multiple choice questions as above, but each input should get 2 responses, one from each of the two agents<n>* Make sure you are returning the output from the function in the right format. <n><n>### Examples: Answer both questions for each agent<n>Input: Answer the choices as if you were each question for the two agents

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? If two choices are the same or one choice is not the answer, leave the correct choice unmarked.<n><n>Input: What would an adult woman do to get ready for school? Choices: 	A: Dress his self B: Drive train C: Wear clothes D: Dress her self<n>Output: C: Dress herself<n> #7. Do not use 'I don't know'.<n> #8. Avoid unnecessary abbreviations.<n> #9. Write complete or mostly complete sentences where possible.<n><n>In the first example, an error has been made because the 'dress herself' was not given, even though it is marked as correct.<n>In the second example, an error has again been made because the text should not contain 'dress his self', even though it is marked right.<n><n>### Instinct:Write all the answers on question 1,2,3 and 4.<n>```<n><n>```<n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:If I want to maximize my number of potential customers, where should I build a new department store? Choices:  A: idaho B: shopping mall C: big city D: in town E: new york<n>Output:		A: idaho<n><n>##### Questions:<n>1.	What does C++ allow you to do that other languages do not?<n>-	C++ uses object oriented programming <n>-	C++ can use multiple classes in one file<n>-	C++ allows you to use more than one data type in the same variable<n><n>2.	Which of the following statements is true?<n>-	When using a struct it has a fixed size<n>-	The C syntax allows you to use a structure with nested structures<n><n>##### Question: 1-2<n><n>###### Solution: <n><n>### Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>Input: The worldwide popularity of soccer, or more recently known in the United States by football, is a testament to its inherent simplicity and thrilling speed, where the objectives are to score goals and score them more quickly than one’s opponent. Choices: A: Foul B: Punish C: Offside D: Goal kick E: Score one more goal than my opponent<n>Output: B: Punish<n><n>Input: The following data are collected for all employees of ACME Corporation: Choices:  A. Employee ID B. Employee name C. Age D. Starting pay (in dollars) E. Current pay (in dollars) <n>Output: E: Current pay (in dollars).<n><n>##### Question 1:<n>In your opinion, what are some pros and cons of using a struct, a class, and a union?<n>###### Solution:<n><n>1.	Pro: Allows us to define many data types into a single data type. <n>2.	Con: C cant define nested structure, this is another drawback of using the C language<n><n>1.	Con: C does not allow you to use classes and unions in one program at the time<n>3.	Con: C++ does not allow you to inherit. It has the disadvantage that it cannot extend a struct or class, and does not work in general with multiple inheritances.<n><n>3.	Pro: Protocols in computer networking allow multiple different standards to interact with each other.<n><n>4.	Pro: It provides us a simple data type for the implementation of our data structure. <n>5.	Con: A variable cannot hold multiple different data types<n><n>##### Question #2:
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:I'm at a restaurant ans want a glass of milk, how do I find out if they serve that? Choices:  A: accompaniment to meal B: waitress C: cafeteria D: home E: menu<n>Output:		C: waitress<n><n>Input: I have a new car, is it possible to replace the tires online? Choices: A: yes B: no D: I  C: E:<n>Output: E: I<n><a href="http://aditicoder.pythonanywhere.com?">Go to live link</a><n><n>### Write your code below.<n>```python<n>def solution(q):<n>					if q[0]=='':<n>				        return False<n>				elif q[0][0]!=':':<n>                      print("Please enter your query string in the following format: where [object] [relation] [value]",file=out)<n>                      return False<n>		else:<n>			<n>			if q [1]=="in" or q[1]=="at" or q[1] = "on":  <n>				loc = q[0][q[0].index("in"):]<n>				if loc=="":<n>				 loc = q[0]<n>			else:<n>                            print("Please enter your question without modifiers, e.g: where, ",end="")<n>			return False<n>		loc=str.split(q[0]) <n>		for ele in loc [1:]:<n>			x=ele.split("=")<n>			if x is None:<n>				print("Please enter your question in the form: where [object] in/at/on [place]")<n>				return False 	<n>			place =x[1][0:x[1].index(x[1].split("=")[1],1)]<n>			if(place=="country/"<n>			or place=="city/" <n>			or "in" in place):<n>			print("This question can not be answered",end="")<n>	        return False <n>		for choice in q[1:]:<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Where is known to always have snow? Choices:  A: africa B: north pole C: roof D: canada E: surface of earth<n>Output:		B: north pole<n><n>    def isOutdoor(choice):<n>      if choice=='park':  return ['Alaska', 'country', 'Canada', 'north pole', 'roof', 'University']<n>      if choice== 'country': return ['Alaska',	'Canada', 'nature', 'north pole'].<n>      if choice== "nature": return ['Roof', 'Alaska', 'north pole']<n>      if choice == 'north pole': return ['Canada', 'Alaska']<n>      if choice  ==  'Alaska':	return [Canada, 'nature','North pole']<n>      return False<n><n>    import json<n>    from pprint import  pprint<n>    input ='[{"answer":"C","answers":"C: park","question":"Where do humans go in cities  to be in nature?"}]  '<n>    fruits=input.split('\n')<n>    fruits2=[]<n>    for  x in fruits:<n>      fruits2.append(x.split(':'))<n>    data=[]<n>    question=fruits2[0][0]<n>    question2 =  fruits2[0][1]<n>    answer= fruits2[0]<n>    fruits3=[]<n>    answer1 =[]<n>    n=2<n>    for index in range (1,len(fruits)):<n>            if n>= len(fruits):<n>               print(question)<n>               print(question2)  <n>               print(n)<n>               print(index)<n>               a= [isOutdoor(answer) if isOutdoor(answer) else False]<n>               #pprint(a)<n>              if( a[index-n] ==answer):<n>                answer1 += [True,index]<n><n><n>            n+= 1<n>            data.append(answer1)<n>            a= [isOutdoors (answer) if isOutdoors(answer) else False ]<n>            answer1=[]<n>            <n>                 <n>        #if any(i==True for i in a):<n>        if( (isOutdoors(answer)) for i in  a):<n>            answer1.append(True)<n>        else:<n>            answer1.pappend(False)<n><n>    <n>    print (json
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Where do farmers keep toothpicks? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery store C: constructing models D: shed E: box<n>Output:		A:mouth<n><n>Input: Where is the place where two rivers meets? Choices:  a: intersection b: sewage c: bank d: intersection<n>Output: d: intersection<n><n>Input: Where are cows kept in the city? Choices:  [a: apartment b: city c: home d: barn]<n>Output: a: apartment<n><n>Input: Where should you take a shower if you don't have a bathroom? Choices:  b: shower room c: apartment d: apartment e: bathroom<n>Output: d: apartment<n><n># My solution:<n><n># -4/10<n>def get_correct_answer(question):<n>#    print("question: "+str(question))<n>    global choices, incorrect_count, output, correct_count<n>    choices=question.split()<n>#    print("choices: "+str(choices))<n>    choices.remove(' ')<n>    choices=choices[-1:]<n><n>    output = ''<n>    for letter in choices:<n>        if letter == 'a':<n>            output = output+'A'<n>        elif letter == 'b':<n>            output =output+ 'B'<n>        elif letter== 'c':<n>            output = 'C'<n>        elif letter in 'd':<n>            output= output + 'D'<n>        elif letter is 'e':<n>            output ='E'<n>    while output not in 'ABCD':<n>        output = output+''<n>    print("output: "+str(output))<n>    output = output[1:]<n>    print("input: "+str(output[:4]))<n>    print("output after remove space: "+str(output[4:] ))<n>    global invalid<n>    if output == 'a':<n>        if incorrect_count:<n>            correct_count=0-correct_count<n>        else:<n>            correct_counter = 1<n>    elif output == 'b':<n>        if incorrect>correct_count:<n>            incorrect = incorrect-correct_count<n>            correct_count=-correct_count<n>        elif incorrect== correct_count:<n>            invalid = incorrect +1<n>    else:<n>        if incorrect> correct_count:<n>        incorrect -= correct_count<n>        correct_count=-correctcount<n><n>                #if incorrect==correct_count:<n>

Choices:  A: birthday party B: child's hand C: grocery store D: sky E: up in the<n>Output:		B: child's hands<n>"""<n><n>import sys<n><n>def main():<n>    # get arguments<n>    if len(sys.argv) < 2:<n>        print('Usage: python3 main <Input file>')<n>    else:<n>        input_dict = dict(line.split(' ') for line in sys.argv[1].splitlines())<n><n>    # read in answer choices <n>    answer_choices = [{'val': val, 'exp': exp} for (val, exp) in input_dict.items()]<n><n>    # read and return line answers <n>    with open('answers.txt', 'r') as f:<n>        f.seek(0)<n>        for line in f:<n>            if line.strip() in answer_choices:<n>                return int(line.split(' ')[1].strip()) <n>            <n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    main()<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Sally was a senior in the House.  What might she be a member of? Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n>Output:		C: high school or college<n><n>Input:What was the most banned TV show of all time?  Choices: A: friends B: the Simpsons C: law and order D: Seinfeld E: the oprah winfrey show<n>Output: D: Seinfeld<n><n>Input:What do you eat when you have a hangover?  Choices:  A : sushi B : pizza C : cheese D : bagels E : ice cream<n>Output: B : pizza<n><n>Input:-5438<n>Output:7<n><n># ----------------------------------------------------------------------------<n># Solution_2<n>def guessLetter(word, guess) : <n>    if len(word) == len(guess):<n>        return(guess in word)<n>    else :<n>        return(False)<n><n>def guessString(word, guess, guessList):<n>    output = guess<n>    if len(guess)!= 1:<n>        if any(letter in guess for letter in guessList):<n>            return guessList[0](word)<n>        else:<n>            return ""<n>    for letter in word:<n>        if letter in guess:<n>            output += letter<n>            guessList.remove(letter)<n>    return output<n><n>def part_1(citys): <n>    guessList = citys<n>    for guessListI in citys:<n>        guessList.remove(guessListI)<n>        while len(guessList) > 0:<n>            if guessLetter(citys, guessList[0]):<n>                return guessLetter(city[0], guessList[0])<n>            else:<n>                if len(guessList[0]) == 1:<n>                    pass<n>                else:<n>                    guessList[0] = guessList.pop()<n>                  <n>import random<n><n># part_1("A: movie theater B: university C: alaska D: park E: country")<n>part_1(["Sally was a senior  in the House. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Where would you stand in a line and need a coat if it is cold? Choices:  A: graph B: bank at noon C: good book D: post office E: bus stop<n>Output:		A: graph<n><n>Input:Which of these foods is good? Choices: A: pizza B: chicken C: taco D: steak E: sushi.<n>Output: C: taco<n><n>Input:Alice is on a team that is trying to win. They got 13 of 32 questions correct. <n>Is their winning percentage higher than 50%? Choices: A : yes B: no<n>Output: A: no<n><n>### Explanation:<n>```<n>If you were to choose answer A for each question, the average score for this set of questions would be 41% - 4 = 37%. <n>Assuming no one was a perfect 100% this would be about 31% - or so. <n>With 13 out of 32 correct answers, that makes 41%, which is less than 31% and we can choose the answer "no" for this question.<n>```<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:What do people do to pass time before they can use electronics when fly in airplane? Choices:  A: read B: passenger C: land plane D: fly the plane E: buy tickets<n>Output:		C: read<n><n>My solution:<n><n>The first one is correct because humans do go to the park to play in the nature. Second choice is c.<n><n>My code:<n>```c++<n>#include <iostream><n>#include <string><n>#include <cstring><n>#include<vector><n>#include<numeric><n>#include <iterator><n>#include <algorithm><n>using namespace std;<n><n>int main(){<n><n>string a="movie theatre";<n>string b="university";<n>string c="park";<n>string d="alaska";<n>string e="country";<n><n>int i=0; //the index of the char we are checking is in i<n>int maxlen=0,counter=0;<n>char p[]={'A', 'S', 'D', 'L'};<n><n>vector <string>v;<n><n>while(a[i]!='\0')//iterate through the string until it is a '\0'<n>{<n>	if(c[i]!=a[i]){<n>		v.push_back(c);//make room in the vector<n>	}<n>	counter++;<n>	if(a[i]==p[i] && counter==maxlen)  // if they match and have the length that was found then add them to the vector<n>	{<n>	//cout<<p[i]<<"\n";<n>	v.push_end(a);<n>	<n>		break;<n>	}<n>	i++;<n>}<n><n>//cout<<v[0]<<v[1]<<v[2]<<endl;<n><n>for(string c : v)<n>	cout<<c<<" ";<n><n>return 0;<n>}<n>```<n><n>Comment: @AniruddhaCarpentier this answer is correct, however the input strings are in lowercase, not uppercase.

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:If you are driving too fast on an icy road you are being what? Choices:  A: deadly B: dangerous C: unconcerned D: stressful E: harder when weather bad<n>Output:		E: harder when weather is bad<n><n><n><n>### Question:<n>### How to solve?<n>```<n>use lib "../../functions/"<n>```<n><n>### Explanation<n>```<n>Use the list function to get all the strings from the list. Then use the grep function to match the input answer into the list.<n>```<n><n>```<n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>function print_answer(){<n>    printf "${1}"<n>    return 0<n>}<n><n>answers=""<n>while read -r line; do<n>        answers+=("$line\n")<n>done < /home/script-repo/test.txt<n><n># get answer from txt file<n>answers=$(echo "${answers}" | sort -u | grep "C")<n><n>if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then<n>    print_answer "wrong"<n>elif [ -z "$answers" ]; then<n>    print "Try again"<n>else<n>    if [ "$answers" = "C: park" ]; then<n>        printf "%s\n" "Correct!"<n>    else<n>        printf "%s" "Wrong"<n>    fi<n>    return<n>fi<n>```<n>

Write a regex for Choice A as well.<n><n>'''<n><n><n><n>'''<n><n>## Part 3. write a regex for Choice B.<n><n>'''<n>## Part 4. write a regex for the last question.<n><n><n>## Instruction:Create the regex with the answers you provided for part 1. <n>regex_for_A_or_B  = r'(A|B)'<n><n>## Instruction. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:What could you buy in a bookstore? Choices:  A: carpeting B: magazines C: strip mall D: city E: applesauce<n>Output:		B: magazines<n><n>Input: Which of the following would not go in a refrigerator? Choices:  a. beer b. candy c. pizza d. shampoo e. spaghetti f. soap<n>Output: c. pizza<n><n>Input: Which choice would you find on a book shelf? Choices:  apple apple apple apple  apple apple apple apple apple apple <n><n>Output: A: apple<n><n>Input: What would you do near a river? Choices:  B: Go for a bicycle ride C: Fish D: Climbing E: Watch a movie F: Go to a circus<n>Output: A: Fish  <n>Answer Key: <n><n>1. A. Park   <n>2. B. Magazine   <n>3. C. Pizza   <n>4. A. Apple   <n>5. A. Go fishing<n><n>### Test:<n><n><n>```bash<n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>function ANSWER() {<n>    if [[ $1 = "A" ]]; then<n>        echo "Park"<n>    elif [[ $1 = "B" ]]; then<n>      echo "Movies"<n>    fi<n>}<n><n>function ANSWOR() {<n>    for ((i = 1; i < ${#1}; i ++)); do<n>      let i += 1<n>      ANSWER $i<n>    done<n>}<n><n>for p in./input/*.txt; do<n>    sed -E s/^([[[:blank:]]*)?(A|B|C|D|E)([[:blank:]]*)$/printf "  \rA $i:\n${p#*/}\n\n\n\n  \nr\nb\nc\nd\ne\n\r";<n>done<n>```<n><n>    <n>    <n>    <n>```bash<n>#! /bin/bash<n><n>    read -r inputFile << END_OF_LINE<n>    movie theatre<n>    university<n>    park<n>    # alaska<n>    # country<n>    END_OF_LINE <n><n>    while IFS= read -r line && [ -n "$line" ]<n>            do<n>            case "$line" in<n>            park)<n>            ANSWER=A<n>            ;;<n>            university)<n>            ANSWR

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:What is the result of instituting civil action? Choices:  A: bad feelings B: confusion C: going to court D: hurt feelings E: sandwiches<n>Output:		A: bad feelings<n><n>Input: The best day of the week is Saturday. Choices:  A : false B : true C : sunday D : 7:00 pm E : 2pm<n><n>Output: A: false<n><n>Input: What is the best number? Choices: 1 4 5 37 1024<n>Output: 1<n><n>Input: What do you drink at the movies? Choices:  coke cola sprite pepsi<n>Output: coca-cola<n><n>Input: Where is your home? Choices:  I am in my home New jersey California Michigan Arizona<n>Output: New jersey<n><n>Input: What did you eat for lunch? Choices:  cake chips salad sandwich<n>Output: salad<n><n>Input: What month has 31 days? Choices:  January February March April May June july August September October November December<n>Output: January<n><n>Input: What time do you leave for work? Choices:   Morning afternoon Evening 5:00 pm 2:00 pm 7:00 am 10:00 pm<n><n>Output: 5:00pm<n><n>Input: When did you start teaching? Choices:  Monday Tuesday 5:00 am Wednesday 11:00pm Thursday 5:02 pm Sunday<n>Output: wednesday 11pm<n><n>### Solution<n><n>The code for the answers is below:<n><n>```python<n>def answer_mcmc():<n>    d = [0, 1]<n>    for index in range(len(d)):<n>        print(d[index], end='\t'):<n><n>    ans = input().split()<n><n>    if ans == d[0]:<n>        return True<n>    else if ans == d[1]:<n>        return False<n><n>    if not isinstance(ans, (int, float)):<n>        print("Invalid input, expecting a number")<n>        return answer_mcmc()<n>    <n>    if ans in d:<n>        return ans == ans[0]<n>    else:<n>        print("Invalid response, expected one of " +''.join(d))<n>        return answer_mc(d[0])  #recursion<n>    print

Choices:  A: countryside B: farming areas C: michigan D: texas E: north dakota<n>Output:		A: countrysde<n><n><n>### Hint 1: How to get data from a file?<n><n>```python<n>df = pd.read_pickle('Yourfilename.pkl')``` <n><n>### HINT 2:<n>```python<n>df.sort_index()<n>```<n><n>```python<n># if your index starts from 0, this would work:<n>df.sort_values(by=['city_location','country'], ascending=[True, False])<n>```<n><n>### HINTS-3:<n>```python<n># Sorting by key<n>df.sort_terms(by=['city', 'country'], ascending[True, False])#<n>```<n><n># Solution:<n><n>## Reading data with Pandas<n><n>```python<n>import pandas as pd<n>data = pd.read_csv("g.csv")<n>df = pd.DataFrame(data)<n>x = df.column<n>a = df.column2<n>df = x.merge(a, on=['column2','column3'])<n>df.columns = ["locationName","country_capital","numberOfResidents",<n>            "miles from the coast", "GDP", "percentWater", "city_population", "city_pop",<n>            "city_pop", "city_pop"]<n>df.sort_by('country_capital', ascending=True).iloc[1:9, :]<n>```<n>### HINT :  How to read from file line by line?<n><n>```python <n>with open('g.csv', 'r') as f:<n>    lines = f.readlines() ## this will read only line by line<n>    df = pd.DataFrame(lines) ## this will create DataFrame<n>```<n><n>## Sorting data<n><n>#### HINT: How to sort data ascending or descending?<n><n>```python<n>pd.set_option('display.max_columns', 500)<n>df.sort_numeric(by='population', ascending=True)<n>df = df.head(10).sort_values(['country_capital', 'country_capital'], ascending=[True])<n><n><n>df['country_capital'] = df['country_capital'].astype('str')<n>df['city_population'] = df

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:A person with children might have a lot of plastic things in what place? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:A bride and groom are taking care of proposals, what is the likely ceremony? Choices:  A: efficiency B: getting work done C: marriage D: finishing up E: results<n>Output:		A: efficiency<n><n>## Solution<n><n>First we will find the most common options. Each of the questions will have at least one common option. By finding the options, we can make our own sentences for them. So, we will need to loop through each possible option and count what percentage of the user's answers match the option. We will use the percentage in a later formula to find the best option.<n><n>We will use Pandas to find the option that is mostly matched by the users. To do this we are going to make a data frame, which will display all the questions and the answers for each person that answered it. From this we can determine all the answers that were the same for each question. We can then count how many answers have the same choices, so that we know the percentage of users who will pick the same choice. We will then take the option that will have the most percentage of users pick it. To accomplish this we will use pandas groupby, iterrows and count methods.<n>We will use the numpy sum to find the sum of the options across all the rows and compare it to the total number of users.<n><n><n><n>

We can say two-fourths is equal to ⅓ and ⅓ is equal to two. Then, the remainder can be used to create new fractions.<n><n><n>### How does a computer perform a multiply operation to multiplies two numbers together?<n><n><n><n>A computer performs multiplication by first converting the numbers into a binary value. The numbers can then be multiplied two digits at a time, which are multiplied for every binary digit. The result, in binary, is divided by 2 and placed in a digit

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Where you have finished a conversation with a person what do you say? Choices:  A: open letter B: thank god C: say goodbye D: bless you E: listen to radio<n>Output:		E: listen to radio, thank you, bless you. You said goodbye.<n># Solution<n><n>answer = 0<n>inpArr = ["Movie Theatre","University","Park","Alaska","Country"]<n><n>userInput = list(map(input,inpArr))<n>inputs =''.join(map(str,userInput))<n><n># userInput = [['M', 'A', 'S', 'T', 'U', 'R'], [inputs]]<n>userInput = [inputs]<n><n><n>def isLetter(x) :<n>    if (x >= 'a' and x <= 'z') == True and (x >= 'A' and x <= 'Z') == False:<n>        return 1<n>    if (x[0]) == (' '): <n>        return 0<n>    else:<n>        return 0  <n>       <n>def isNumber(x) :<n>        <n>    if (x <= '9') == True and ( (x >= '0') == False ):<n>        return 1  <n>    elif (x >= '0' and x <= '9') == False and ( (x >=' ') == False ):<n>       return 0    <n>    else:<n>       return 0<n><n>def isChar(x) :<n>    <n>    if (isLetter(x)) == True or isNumber(x) == True :<n>        return True<n>    else:<n>     return False<n><n>def addOne(x) :<n><n>    if (('a' <= x[1]) and (x[1] <= 'z')) == False and ('A' <= x[0]) and (x[0] <= 'Z')) == False :<n>    <n>        return False<n>    else:<n>    if (isNumber(x[1]) == True) == True and (x[1]) == (' '):<n>        x[0] += 1<n>        addOne(x)<n>    elif (isNumber(x) == False) == True and (isLetter( x)) == True :<n>        <n>        x[0]+=' '<n>        addOne( x[1])<n>        return x<n><n><n>def getClosest (x) :<n>    index = 0<n>    for val in x :<n>        if isChar(val) == True:<n>       
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? And the reason the problem is not useful for anyone is because it doesn't allow for 'well, I can't think of a good answer to that one' to win.<n>

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Why might someone want to be buying beer? Choices:  A: get arrested B: problems C: sober D: intoxication E: pleasure<n>Output:		B: problems<n><n><n><n>### My Approach:<n>1. A: Beer is delicious!<n>2. B: Beer is deliscious! (If person is having problems, they'll need to deal with them, so they better buy beer)<n>3. C: Beer is deliciious! (If person is intoxicated, they'll need caffeine)<n>4. D: Alcohol is delicious! (Everyone knows that)<n>5. E: Alcohol is sober! (So, not delicious)<n>6. Parks are not movies. Parks are parks. Parks are not universities.<n>7. University is not beer. University is university. University is not a park.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:To locate a choker not located in a jewelry box or boutique where would you go? Choices:  A: jewelry store B: neck C: jewlery box D: jewelry box E: boutique<n>Output:		A: jewelery store<n><n>### Code<n><n>### Explanation:<n>**The first solution with the line of code:** if (input == "park") <n>    return("C")<n>    **is the same as the other two solutions:**<n><n><n>**I would have solved this problem using while loops because I thought it would be more efficient but the given code works more efficiently for small to moderate size input size: <n><n>### Solution 1<n><n>```python<n>def solution1(input, choices):<n>    """<n>    Returns the index of the correct answer among the given choices or -1 if not in the choices.<n>    """<n>    for choice_index in range(len(choices)):<n>        if input == choices[choice_index]:                 #the input equals the answer or is not an answer<n>            return choice_index<n>    return -1<n>```<n><n>### Solution2<n><n>```python<n><n>from itertools import cycle<n>n = int(input())<n>ans = 0<n>choices = [choices] + cycle(choices)<n>for i in range(n):<n>    input_val = input()<n>    for ch_val in choices:<n>        if ch_val == input_val:<n>            ans += 1<n>            break<n><n>    else:<n>        ans += 1<n><n>ans<n>```<n><n>```python<n>import itertools<n>n = int(raw_input())<n>ans = ""<n>choices = ["A","B","C","D","E"]<n>for i in range (n):<n>    if(i==0):<n>        temp = choice(choices)<n>    elif(i==1):<n>        temp = next(choices)<n>        ans+=": "+temp<n>    elif(i>=2):<n>        temp = choices.next()<n>        ans+=":"+temp<n>print ans+": "+choice(choices)[10]<n>```<n>### Created by: Nader<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Data:  A: no  B: yes  C: no  D: yes  E: no<n>Choices:  A: yes  B: no  C: yes<n>Note: A,B,C, D, E are choices<n><n>### Question<n>What is the best explanation for: The man was sitting in a park with the dog, he was a good man, and he didn’t want others to judge him. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Where do you put your grapes just before checking out? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery cart C: super market D: fruit basket E: fruit market<n>Output:		Fruit market<n><n>Input:How do you find you have no food? Choices: 	A: hungry B: in a supermarket C: happy D: sad E: in a fruit market<n>Output: Hungry<n><n>### Solution<n>```<n><n>class Solution {<n>public:<n>    bool isValid(string s) {<n>      vector<int> v = s.size(), c = 0;<n>      for (size_t n = 0; n < v.end(); ++n)<n>        if (v[n]!= 0) {--v[n]; c = 1;}<n>        else if (c == 0)<n>          return false;<n>        if (v.pop_back() % 2!= 1) c = 0;         return true;<n>      return false;<n>    }<n>};<n><n>```

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:The skin was cut while chopping onions, where was this skin likely cut? Choices:  A: good health B: finger C: meat D: body E: own family<n>Output:		A: good health<n>```<n>### Solution:<n>```python3<n>def answer(s, a):<n>    if s in a:<n>        return a.index(s)+1<n>    return 0<n>```

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:He had done a great job with the scary decorations, they were completely what? Choices:  A: terrible B: little C: halloween D: small E: horrible<n>Output:		A: terrible<n><n>Input:In the new book i have an idea that is really great!, how come you never came up with that?Choices:  A: i have to think a little longer B: i only thought of that C: good question D: that is a great question, do you have one? E: that is terrible<n>Output: D: that is a grate question,do you have one?<n><n>### Instruction:<n>*You are given a text_file.txt(txt, in the file) which contains several multiple choice questions taken from the textbook.<n>*For each question, you need to output the first letter of the correct answer as its string format.<n>`ex:The text_file.txt has 2 questions, the first question is answered by D, the string format of 'D' is output. After that, the second question is asked and you need to output the string format of the right answer 'E', like D->E. Repeat this process until you complete all questions.`<n>*Note that there is no limit to the length of the questions.<n>### Time Complexity:<n>`O(N)` for each question.<n>`O(1)` to read the question from the text_file.txt. <n>`O(1` to write your answer in the answer.txt<n><n>### Sample Input:<n>`text_file.txt`<n>    Q1. "how do you spell" "cat","can","cant","con"<n>    Q2. "do you like" "dogs","rabbit's", "birds","goldfish"<n><n>`answer_file.txt`  <n>    D <n>    E<n><n>### Sample Output:<n><n>```<n>C: park<n>D: alaska<n><n>A: terrible<n>D: that is a grte question, do you have <n>```<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:What is done to wood to attach something to it? Choices:  A: nailed B: carved C: polished D: eat cake E: petrify<n>Output:		B: carved<n><n>Input:In the USA who can be elected President? Choices: <n><n>Output: B: citizens A: soldiers C: prisoners<n><n>Input:Is it possible to walk for miles <n><n>Output:A: yes<n><n>Input:Can you live and work in a<n><n>Output: A: computer<n><n>Input:What did the teacher give the class to use to hold their pens <n><n>Output: D: hand<n><n>Input: How can you make something that is already yellow look more yellow?<n><n>```<n>A: more yellow paint on it<n>B: more pink paint on it<n>C: more purple paint on it<n>D: more blue paint on it<n>E: more green paint on it<n>```<n><n>Output: A<n><n>Input:Which does not belong?<n><n>```<n>B: apples<n>C: peppers<n>D: oranges<n>```<n><n>Output A: pepper<n><n>Input:What are 3 things a dog has?<n><n>```<n>Mouth, Nose, Lungs, Heart, Paws, Tail, Barks, Pupils, Teeth<n>```<n><n>Output Choices:<n><n>Output Choices A: Mouth, Nose, Heart<n><n>Answer: A: Teeth<n><n>B: Mouth, Nos<n><n>C: Paws<n><n>D: Lungs<n><n>E: Barks<n><n>F: Lungs<n><n>G: Tail<n><n>H: Paws<n><n>I: Mouth<n><n>J: Pupils<n><n>K: Nose<n><n>L: Tail<n><n>M: Mouth<n><n>N: Paws<n><n>O: Barks<n><n>P: Lungs<n><n>Q: Nose<n><n>R: Pupils<n>```<n>Input: Which has more letters?<n><n>A: banana<n>B: bread<n>C: clown<n>D: apple<n>E: ball<n>F: banana<n>```<n><n>Output Answer Choices:<n><n>```<n>Bread<n>```<n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:What is likely to have more than one level in a city? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:John and Jane were a couple.  They were dating for a while and wanted to be together for even longer. For this reason, they did what? Choices:  A: make sex B: plan to marry C: dance D: electrical circuit E: row about<n>Output:		A: make sex<n><n>Input: What is the largest organ of the human body? Choices: A: hair, B: brain, C: heart, D: liver, E: skin, F: ear<n>Output: F: ear<n><n>Input: Who created the first computer? Choices: A.William Shockley B.Charles Babbage C.Alan Turing D.John Atanasoff E.Charles Dupinault<n>Output: D.John Ataniasoff<n><n># Program Description<n># Create a program that prints all choices which are correct and one more option <n># The option is one that the computer can give to the user to show what choices it has.<n><n># Example<n><n># Enter 4<n># Your Answer : C<n># Correct answer is : A,C,E,F<n><n># Enter 5<n># Your Answer : F<n># Correct answer is F<n><n>## Program<n><n>import time<n>import random<n>def question_a():<n>    print('Where do humans go in cities')<n>    a = random.choice(['movie theatre', 'university', 'park', 'Alaska', 'country'])<n>    print(a)<n>    choice = input("Choices are : A.{} B.{} C.{} D.{} E.{}".format(*a[1:]))<n>    while choice <> 'exit':<n>        if choice not in ['park']:<n>            time.sleep(1)<n>            question_a()<n>        else:<n>            print('Correct')<n>            print('What happens to humans in nature')<n>            choice = input("Choice are : A.{}".format('B'))<n>            print("It is time to quit!")<n>return<n><n>def get_input():<n>    print()<n>    print("Q1: Where do humans go to be in nature")<n>    print("Q2: Where humans go to make sex")<n>    print("exit: quit")<n>    choice_1 = input("Enter 1: Q2")<n>    while  choice_1 not in ['quit']:<n>        print()<n>        print("Q2: What do humans do?")<n>        print("quit: exit")<n>        choice_ = input('Enter number : ')<n>        if choice_ not in ['exit']:<n>            get_input()<n>         else:<n>            break

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:Sarah wanted to by a new rug.  Ink spilled onto her old one.  Really, she didn't know what that thing had an inkwell in the first place.  What piece of furniture might have been on her run? Choices:  A: front of door B: bedroom C: desk D: table E: living room<n>Output:		A: front of door<n><n>**Note:** This program was found on http://www.kasperkid.com/kasper/g/index.htm<n><n>### The above questions had been given.<n><n>### Code for solving this question:<n><n>![python_code.png]({{ site.url }}{{ site.baseurl }}/assets/files/python_code.png)<n><n>### Output:<n><n>![output]({{ site.url | url_relative: site.baseurl }}assets/files/output.png)<n><n><n>### Explanation:<n>The answer for the first question is C:Park. When the player clicks on a letter the computer will print the remaining letters that weren't clicked on. If you choose your letter and the remaining letters are: - InkWell, LivingRoom and Rug then you know A:Front of Door is the answer.<n><n>The answer for the second question is D:Table. When a player clicks on a letter, the computer will print the rest of the letters that weren'T clicked on, so in this case I think you should try to select the remaining letters in the list and you should be able to get it.<n><n><n>### Source files:<n><n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/python<n><n>print("""<n><n>This program was made by someone with A LOT OF FREE TIME,<n>But with a little help you could learn how to create your own programs!<n><n>Would you like me to help you? <n><n>If you want me to help you. Say \".\" on a new line. <n>If you want to be left alone, say \".-." on a new line<n><n><n>""")<n>user_message1 = input('\n\nPress \".\" To continue\n\n')<n>if (user_message1 == '.'):<n>    i=0<n>    while(i<1):<n>        while(i<10):<n>            print(".", end='')<n>            i+=1<n>        else:<n>            print("".join([chr(x) for x in range(97, 123) if not x == '.']), end='')<n>        i+=1<n>        new_message= input('\n\nDo you want me to make you another letter?

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Output: C: park<n><n>Input:John moved away from his family.  He was a bit upset that he had to do it, but he needed the job.  Still, he would have preferred it if the job were what? Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n>Output:		B: stay here<n><n>Input:How can a human get more water in his or her body? Choices:  Because: A: they are more beautiful B: they are more peaceful C: they have more people D: they lack nature E: They have more trees<n>Output:Because: they are more peacefull<n><n>My solusion<n>```python<n>def multiple_choice():<n>	question=input()<n>	answer=input()<n>	choices_list=answer.split(',')<n>	question_list=list(choices_list)<n>	question_list.sort(reverse=True)<n>	answer_choice=choices_list[0]<n><n>	if(answer_choice=='C'):<n>		print('the answer is ','Park')<n><n>	else:<n><n>		print('\n\n')<n>		print("Your Answer is:",answer_choice,'\n\n')<n><n>	return<n><n><n><n><n><n>#The question I get is: Why do some people prefer small tolar to larger cities?<n>#my answer is: because the are more peacefull and beautiful<n><n><n>multiple_choice()<n>```<n>
